title: 103_hr2761
content:
The Act titled "Ocean and Coastal Management Improvement Act of 1993" transfers offices of National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration to the Department of the Interior. Transfer of offices and assets from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration to the Department of the Interior includes the National Ocean Service, National Marine Fisheries Service, Office of Oceanic and Atmospheric Research, research and survey vessels fleet, and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Corps. Functions of transferred offices' employees are now under the Secretary of the Interior, who will delegate these functions accordingly. The functions of various programs within the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration are being delegated to different departments within the Department of the Interior. This includes functions related to national marine sanctuaries, mapping, charting, geodesy, marine fisheries, and oceans and Great Lakes programs. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration is transferring functions related to oceans and Great Lakes programs, marine prediction research, the National Sea Grant College Program, and undersea research to the Department of the Interior. Additionally, coastal ocean science functions performed by the National Ocean Service will also be transferred. Advisory committees of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration that primarily concern these functions will also be transferred to the Department of the Interior. Transfer of components of National Ocean Service to Department of Environmental Protection. Transfer of Offices and Functions from the National Ocean Service to the Department of Environmental Protection includes observation, assessment, coastal management programs, estuarine reserve research, and coastal pollution control functions. The Secretary of the Environment transfers officers and employees from a component to their department. An Assistant Secretary is designated to oversee the transferred components and their functions. Advisory committees from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration are also transferred to the Department of Environmental Protection. TRANSFER OF PROPERTY, RECORDS, AND PERSONNEL. The contracts, liabilities, records, property, and assets of offices transferred to the Secretary of the Interior or the Secretary of the Environment are allocated accordingly. Personnel employed in connection with these offices are also transferred, with protections against separation or reduction in grade or compensation for a year after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 5. REFERENCES.

References in federal laws, orders, or documents to the Department of Commerce or its components are now deemed to refer to the Department of the Interior or the Department of Environmental Protection. 

SEC. 6. SAVINGS PROVISIONS. All legal documents issued by government officials or courts with respect to transferred functions will remain in effect until modified or revoked by law. The provisions of this Act do not affect ongoing proceedings or applications for benefits, services, licenses, permits, certificates, or financial assistance. Orders issued in these proceedings will remain in effect until modified, terminated, superseded, or revoked by authorized officials or a court of competent jurisdiction. The Act does not impact ongoing proceedings or applications for benefits, services, licenses, permits, certificates, or financial assistance. Orders issued in these proceedings will remain in effect until modified, terminated, superseded, or revoked by authorized officials or a court of competent jurisdiction. Any suits commenced before the enactment of the Act will proceed as if the Act had not been enacted. No actions against the Secretary of Commerce or Under Secretary of Commerce for Oceans and Atmosphere will be affected by the Act. (e) Continuance of Suits.--If any office, component, or officer is party to a suit before the enactment of this Act, and their functions are transferred to the Secretary of the Interior or the Secretary of the Environment, the suit will continue with the new officials substituted or added as parties. SEC. 7 of the Act defines "function" as any duty, power, or program, and "office" as any organizational entity.
